sentence: Home Depot (HD) is set to report first quarter fiscal 2018 earnings results before the opening bell Tuesday.
The world's largest home-improvement retailer — one of the few names shown to be “Amazon (AMZN)-proof” — is expected to deliver a stellar quarter.
Home Depot’s growth is expected to be driven by a combination of events, namely a booming housing market, tax reform and new construction.

Factoring in the strength of the U.S. economy, low unemployment, which has spurred consumers' discretionary income to fuel more home improvement projects, Wall Street also expects Home Depot’s same-store sales growth to be on the higher end of its own forecast.
In the three months that ended April, the Atlanta, GA.-based company is expected to deliver adjusted earnings of $2.06 per share on revenue of $25.1 billion.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when earnings came to $1.67 per share on revenue of $23.89 billion.
For the full year, ending in December, earnings of $9.45 per share would rise 26.67% year over year, while full-year revenue of the $107.87 billion would rise 6.9% year over year.
Home Depot, in the fourth quarter, reported adjusted earnings-per-share of $1.69, while revenue came to $23.9 billion.
Both figures creased by analysts’ expectations for EPS of $1.64, on revenue of $23.7 billion.
On Tuesday Wall Street will want to see evidence that these growth metrics, particularly the full-year profit forecasts, are sustainable.
While the housing market has shown no signs of slowing down, the business side of Home Depot will need to show it warrants a higher stock price.
The company must also show that its improved merchandising and e-commerce strategy can lead to higher same-store sales, which hast been buoyed over the past year.
Fourth quarter same-store sales, which tracks the performances of stores opened at least one year, reached 7.5%, including 7.2% growth in the U.S.
These trends demonstrate stability for Home Depot, particularly in a retail environment that is still being disrupted by e-commerce giant Amazon.

In terms of the top- and bottom growth metrics for the quarter and full year, I’m willing to argue that they underestimated since the company’s effective tax rate — thanks to the federal tax overhaul — is expected to fall to 26%, compared with 35.2% in Q1 2017.

As such, while analysts expect Home Depot’s Q1 profit margins to improve to 9.5% from 8.4%, I expect profit margins to be higher by at least 20 to 30 basis points, driven by lower costs and better operating efficiencies.
Analysts will also focus on the company’s e-commerce presence, which continues to grow.
Online sales, which now accounts for about 7% of revenue, grew 21% in Q4.

And the company is able to leverage its massive store base of 2,300 locations to be used as fulfillment centers for online orders to the extent that roughly half of online orders were picked up in stores.

All told, buoyed by the fact that consumers are spending more money on home-improvement projects, while homebuilders are buying more material to build homes, Home Depot — with the shares still down more than 8% from their 52-week high of $207 — offers of solid foundation for a investors looking to build a portfolio.
